summary: Email from attorney Paul Cassell to an undisclosed recipient, discussing the drafting of a legal response on behalf of victims Jane Doe 1 and 2 to Jeffrey Epstein's claim that victims cannot obtain 'rescission' as a remedy. Cassell offers to share a draft section arguing the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) only covers the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida before filing.

persons.name: Paul Cassell
persons.context: Drafting a legal response on behalf of victims Jane Doe 1 and 2 to Jeffrey Epstein's claim regarding remedies, and offering to share the draft with the recipient's office.

persons.name: Jane Doe 1
persons.context: One of the victims represented by Paul Cassell in the legal proceedings against Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jane Doe 2
persons.context: One of the victims represented by Paul Cassell in the legal proceedings against Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the legal claim regarding victims' inability to obtain 'rescission' as a remedy, related to the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA).

persons.name: Ronald N. Boyce
persons.context: Mentioned in Paul Cassell's email signature as part of his academic title at the S.J. Quinney College of Law.

keyFacts: Attorney Paul Cassell is representing victims Jane Doe 1 and 2 in legal proceedings against Jeffrey Epstein.
The legal dispute involves Epstein's claim that victims cannot obtain 'rescission' as a remedy.
Cassell's draft argues the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) only covers the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.
The email indicates ongoing legal strategy coordination between victim attorneys and an undisclosed office.
The correspondence is dated July 14, 2019, showing post-conviction legal activity related to Epstein's case.
